title: Rotation - Parallel axis theorem for disks

content.description: A uniform disk, Disk <math alttext="A" overflow="scroll"><mtext>A</mtext></math>, of mass <math alttext="m" overflow="scroll"><mi>m</mi></math> and radius <math alttext="R" overflow="scroll"><mi>R</mi></math> rotates about an axis through the disk’s geometric center as shown in Figure <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>. The rotational inertia for the disk in this configuration is <math alttext="I equals one half m R squared" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>I</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mi>m</mi><msup><mi>R</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mstyle></math>. An identical disk, Disk <math alttext="B" overflow="scroll"><mtext>B</mtext></math>, rotates about an axis that passes through the edge of the disk, a radial distance <math alttext="R" overflow="scroll"><mi>R</mi></math> from the center of the disk as shown in Figure <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>. The same torque is exerted on both disks, and disks <math alttext="A" overflow="scroll"><mtext>A</mtext></math> and <math alttext="B" overflow="scroll"><mtext>B</mtext></math> experience angular accelerations <math alttext="alpha sub A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>α</mi><mtext>A</mtext></msub></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="alpha sub B" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>α</mi><mtext>B</mtext></msub></mstyle></math>, respectively.
